projects.name: Sgraffito Pottery

materials.item: Pre-mixed black (or any other colour you like) underglaze

steps.instruction: Choose the clay to use. Fine clay such as stoneware or porcelain works best. Rough and grog clays do not leave a smooth finish when the topcoat is scratched off.

Decide on the form you are going to create, either a plate, bowl, cup or whatever. If it is your first time doing Sgraffito, I suggest that you make a flat object such as a small tile. Once you have created your clay form, let it dry to leather hard.
steps.visual_description: A leather hard clay bowl with a decorative rim.

steps.instruction: Wipe the leather hard clay gently with a soft paintbrush. Any dust left on the surface will cause the glaze to pull away, leaving a bare spot.
steps.visual_description: A paintbrush gently wiping dust off the rim of a clay form.

steps.instruction: Apply 3 to 4 flowing coats of black underglaze to the clay form. Avoid leaving brush strokes which could show up later. Give it time to dry properly, then apply a washed paint effect to the rim. (Add a thin line of paint to the rim and go over with a clean wet brush).
steps.visual_description: A paintbrush applying black underglaze to a clay form. The underglaze is dark and opaque.

tips: Make sure the clay form is leather hard and not too soft or too dry. It must be hard enough to hold its shape when pressure is applied and be easy to carve.
projects.finished_product_description: A pottery piece with an incised decorative technique (Sgraffito) using underglazes.

diagram_descriptions: A leather hard clay bowl with a decorative rim.
A paintbrush gently wiping dust off the rim of a clay form.
A paintbrush applying black underglaze to a clay form. The underglaze is dark and opaque.

projects.name: Sgraffito Clay Decoration

steps.instruction: If you do not feel comfortable with free hand scratching, then first draw your pattern on paper and trace it onto your clay object using a normal HB pencil.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a brush and scratching a pattern onto the edge of a clay object.

steps.instruction: Start being creative by scraping off the underglaze on parts of your design using a sharp pointed tool. Use medium pressure to create a textured contrasting black and white design by revealing the clay colour (white) underneath as you go.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a hand using a pointed tool to scrape underglaze off a clay object, revealing a white pattern underneath.

steps.instruction: Use the soft, large paintbrush to gently remove all shavings/debris as you go, making sure you do not damage your design.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a hand using a large paintbrush to clean debris from a decorated clay surface.

steps.instruction: Be patient, as this can take some time, especially if you have an intricate design. Once you are satisfied, set the clay form aside for drying and bisque firing.
steps.visual_description: Several clay bowls decorated with white patterns on a dark surface, some covered with plastic wrap.

steps.instruction: After bisque firing you have the option to correct any mistakes and to then either apply transparent glaze or not.
steps.visual_description: A hand using a pointed tool to make a small correction on a decorated clay object.

tips: Keep in mind the final colour of each glaze when you choose your design. Colour can change once it has been fired in the kiln.
Sometimes I add extra spots of coloured underglaze to my black and white Sgraffito designs.
projects.finished_product_description: Decorated clay bowls with intricate sgraffito designs.

projects.name: Chalkboard Frame Organizer

materials.item: Chalkboard frame (or any frame that can be painted with chalk paint)

steps.instruction: Paint the outside and inside edges of the frame with craft paint.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the corner of a frame being painted with green craft paint.

steps.instruction: Cut patterned paper and glue onto frame with wood glue.
steps.visual_description: A frame covered with various pieces of patterned paper. The paper has designs of houses, stars, and figures.

steps.instruction: Use sandpaper to roughen up the paper and randomly stamp with the stamp pad.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a small black stamp pad and pressing it onto the patterned paper on the frame.

steps.instruction: Using a Dremel Multitool, cut the tin cans, tin cup and teacup in half.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a Dremel Multitool and cutting a tin can lengthwise.

steps.instruction: Using a sponge and craft paint, dab paint onto the tin cup and tin can.
steps.visual_description: A sponge dabbing brown craft paint onto a cut tin cup and tin can.

steps.instruction: Use a glue gun to adhere the cups and cans to the frame – be very generous with the glue.
steps.visual_description: A finished frame decorated with various items including cut tin cans, hooks, handles, and a teacup. The frame has a chalkboard center.

tips: Visit junk stores to pick up odd bits (hooks, handles, cups, cans) very cheaply.

projects.name: Stenciled Leather Wallet/Cardholder

materials.item: Sharpie pens or fibre tipped pens

steps.instruction: Print pattern out to scale and paste onto firm cardboard or plastic. Cut out along the solid lines and punch the holes to prepare for marking your leather.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand holding a revolving punch plier, punching holes along the edge of a white paper or plastic pattern piece. The pattern piece has a rounded rectangular shape with a long central slit and rows of small holes along the perimeter and the slit.

steps.instruction: Place pattern onto the leather and use a marking pen/pencil to trace the perimeter lines, inside lines and holes. Cut out holes with revolving punch plier.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand holding a marking pen, tracing the outline of the prepared pattern onto a piece of light-colored leather. The pattern is a rounded rectangle with a central slit and rows of small holes.

steps.instruction: Print out your stencil of choice to scale, paste it onto firm plastic or cardboard, cut it out and then trace it onto your prepared leather piece.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand holding a pen, tracing a geometric stencil pattern onto a light-colored leather piece. The stencil has an intricate, tessellated design.

steps.instruction: Colour in stencilled leather with Sharpie pens or fibre tipped pens in your own style. Once completed seal with leather dressing or balm.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a finished leather piece, folded in half, with a colorful geometric pattern (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, purple, pink shapes) colored in. A hand is applying a substance with a cloth to the colored leather. Another photo shows the folded, colored leather piece with various colored markers in the background.

steps.instruction: Place zip face up onto your work surface and stick down the double-sided tape onto the zip in order to secure this to the back of leather opening in preparation for stitching.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a white zipper being prepared. A hand is peeling the backing off a strip of double-sided tape that has been applied to the zipper.

steps.instruction: Begin stitching by threading a needle on both ends of the thread. Push one needle through the first stitching hole and pull the thread through half way only. Stitch the first row of running stitches using one needle. Once you get to the end, go back to where you started and stitch the second row of running stitches using the second needle. This forms a saddle stitch.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand holding two needles, performing a saddle stitch on the colored leather piece. The thread is white, and the needles are passing through the pre-punched holes along the edge of the leather, securing the zipper. Another photo shows the zipper being stitched to the leather, with the colorful pattern visible.

steps.instruction: To secure the end, once you get to the last hole, make a double stitch by stitching through the same hole twice. Knot the two end pieces of the thread (double knot), cut off the ends and burn them with a lighter.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a close-up of the stitching process, with a needle passing through a hole in the leather. The colorful pattern and white thread are visible.

details.line_style: solid lines along perimeter and central slit
rows of small holes along perimeter and central slit

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Attach zipper to the back of the leather opening. Stitch using saddle stitch.

tips: Use Sharpie pens or fibre tipped pens for coloring.
Seal with leather dressing or balm once coloring is complete.
Saddle stitch forms a strong seam.
projects.finished_product_description: A leather item (likely a wallet or cardholder) with a colorful, stenciled geometric pattern, secured with saddle stitching and a zipper.

projects.name: Oreo Cake Pops

tools.name: Jug or mug
tools.purpose: holding hot water for melting decorating chocolate bag

steps.instruction: Cake pop sticks are slightly thicker than the filling of the Oreos. Open the cookie carefully and place the stick on one side. I used a little melted chocolate to set the stick in place. Replace the other side of the cookie onto the warm chocolate and press together.
steps.visual_description: Photo of an Oreo cookie with a white cake pop stick inserted into its cream filling, with the top cookie replaced to form a complete cookie on a stick.

steps.instruction: Place the dipping chocolate in a glass microwave safe bowl.

Melt and stir the chocolate for 10 seconds at a time, until completely melted. Chocolate must be smooth and shiny. Do not overheat or burn the chocolate. If you are using a double boiler or melting pot, melt the chocolate slowly until smooth.
steps.visual_description: Photo of a glass bowl containing melted white chocolate, being stirred with a spoon.

steps.instruction: After the cake pop stick has set in the centre, your Oreo will be ready for dipping. Dip them one by one.
steps.visual_description: Photo of an Oreo on a stick being dipped into a bowl of melted white chocolate, with a spoon gently assisting the dipping process.

steps.instruction: Set aside on wax wrap or baking paper.
steps.visual_description: Photo of a fully dipped Oreo pop, coated in white chocolate, resting on a surface (likely wax paper or baking paper).

steps.instruction: While the chocolate is still soft enough, sprinkle the hundreds-and-thousands over the dipped cookie.
steps.visual_description: Photo of a white chocolate-dipped Oreo pop covered in pink and white hundreds-and-thousands (sprinkles).

steps.instruction: Lay the ones you want to drizzle over next to each another on the baking paper.
Fill a jug or mug with hot (not boiling) water. Place the bag of decorating chocolate in the water and allow the chocolate to melt.
Wipe the bag dry. Snip off a tiny corner from the bag. (Remember the bigger the cut the more chocolate will come out and the thicker your drizzle lines will be.)
Squeezing the bag slightly, drizzle streaks of chocolate over the cookies.
steps.visual_description: Photo of two white chocolate-dipped Oreo pops, each with pink chocolate drizzles in streaks across their surface, lying on a flat surface.

steps.instruction: Sprinkle some sprinkles over them and add confetti hearts.
Repeat the above steps for dark chocolate.
steps.visual_description: Photo showing a collection of six finished Oreo pops on sticks: three dipped in white chocolate with pink drizzles and sprinkles/hearts, and three dipped in dark chocolate with pink drizzles and sprinkles/hearts, all arranged on a surface.

tips: Chocolate must be smooth and shiny. Do not overheat or burn the chocolate. If you are using a double boiler or melting pot, melt the chocolate slowly until smooth.
The bigger the cut [on the bag for drizzling] the more chocolate will come out and the thicker your drizzle lines will be.
projects.finished_product_description: Oreo cookies dipped in white or dark chocolate, decorated with sprinkles, hundreds-and-thousands, and confetti hearts, presented on cake pop sticks.

projects.name: Drewno the Maltese
projects.finished_product_description: A needle-felted Maltese dog.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up photo of a needle-felted Maltese dog sitting in dry grass. The dog is white with dark eyes and a black nose. The title 'Drewno' is in large white letters at the top, followed by 'the Maltese. A Needle Felted Friend!' in smaller white text. The author's name, 'by Charlize Stone', is below that. The page number '18' and 'Craftwise' are in the bottom left corner.

projects.name: Life Size Maltese Dog

steps.instruction: The diagram is a guide as to the size and shape of all the body parts (before the hair has been attached) which will all be made using the white merino roving.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing body parts for a felted dog.

steps.instruction: Start with the head. Pull out as much roving as you need - never cut it. Place it onto the sponge, roll it into a ball shape while poking it with the felting needle until it is nice and solid.
steps.visual_description: A hand rolling white roving into a ball shape on a blue sponge while poking it with a felting needle.

steps.instruction: Make the muzzle and attach it to the head. You can adjust the size and shape of your head by either poking it some more or adding a small amount of roving where needed.
steps.visual_description: A felted head with a muzzle attached. A small piece of purple thread is visible on the muzzle.

steps.instruction: Punch indentations on both sides of the head (above the muzzle) to form the eye sockets. Make sure the eye sockets are aligned.
steps.visual_description: A felted dog head with two indentations on either side of the muzzle, indicating eye socket placement.

steps.instruction: Use strong thread (you can also use dental floss) to insert and secure the eyes. Thread it through the wire loop of the glass eye and thread both ends through the needle.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a glass eye with a wire loop, with thread being threaded through it. A needle is attached to the thread.

steps.instruction: Repeat this step for the other eye and make sure they are aligned. Start with one eye, pull the thread tightly so that the eye appears sunken in its “socket”. Secure the thread under the head by tying a few knots. Repeat with the other eye. Do not worry about the knotted thread sticking out at the bottom of the head, you will cover it up later.
steps.visual_description: A felted dog head with both glass eyes attached and appearing sunken into their sockets. The thread is visible underneath the head.

steps.instruction: Use the black roving to make a little nose. Attach it to the face by carefully needle felting it around the base. Make 2 nostrils by poking little holes on either side of the nose.
steps.visual_description: A completed felted dog head with a black nose and two small nostril holes.

steps.instruction: Pull out small amounts of Tencel, lay it next to each other on the sponge and poke a line through the middle with your needle, dividing the hair in half (see below).
steps.visual_description: A bundle of white Tencel fibers laid out on a blue sponge. A felting needle is poking a line down the middle of the fibers.

steps.instruction: Now add a thin piece of merino over the middle line and felt it onto the Tencel. You now attach the hair by only felting the middle line onto the head. Make sure that you attach the hair so that it falls in the direction you want it to lay.
steps.visual_description: A felted dog head with white Tencel hair being attached to the top of the head. The hair is being felted along a central line.

tips: Enlarge the templates by 200% (Twice the size)
It is easier to pull the eye into the head if the wire loop at the back of the eye is flattened slightly – see photo - for this you can use a small pliers.
projects.finished_product_description: A life-size felted Maltese dog.

projects.name: Needle Felted Dog

steps.instruction: To attach a second piece, lift up the first piece and felt the second one just underneath it. Continue in this manner until the whole face is covered with hair.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a needle-felted dog's face with white wool being attached to cover it, showing a felting needle in use.

steps.instruction: Shape the ears using the merino roving and cover both with hair using the same technique as on the face.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a needle-felted dog's face, with one ear shaped and covered in wool, and the other ear being worked on.

steps.instruction: Attach the ears by placing them between 2 layers of hair and securing them at the base (see photo).
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a needle-felted dog's head, showing the ears being attached between layers of wool hair and secured at the base.

steps.instruction: For the body you'll need about 100 g of white merino roving. Needle felt the body into the shape as shown on the diagram. First attach the hind legs to the body and then the front legs.
steps.visual_description: A needle-felted dog's body, shown from the back, with a felting needle inserted into the neck area. The body is covered in white wool.

steps.instruction: Make sure that your dog can sit and that his front paws touch the ground. (At this stage the body will look like a plucked chicken!)
steps.visual_description: A needle-felted dog's body, shown from the front, sitting with its front paws touching the ground. The body is covered in white wool and has a somewhat rounded shape.

steps.instruction: Add hair to cover the whole body and legs. Leave the top part of the neck edge without hair. You will use it to attach the body to the head.
steps.visual_description: The needle-felted dog's body, covered in white wool, with the legs also covered. The top edge of the neck area is left bare for attachment to the head.

steps.instruction: To attach the head to the body, needle felt the neck edge into the bottom of the head. Turn your dog to needle felt it from different angles.
steps.visual_description: A needle-felted dog's head being attached to its body. A hand is holding a felting needle, securing the neck edge of the head to the body.

steps.instruction: Needle felt a long tail as per diagram leaving a bit of fluff at the base, add hair and attach it to the back of the body (attach it the same way as the ears – between 2 layers of hair).
steps.visual_description: A needle-felted dog's body, shown from the back, with a long tail being attached. The tail is made of wool and is being felted between layers of hair on the back.

steps.instruction: You can trim the long hair around the paws as well as the hair under his mouth if you want.
Shade the nose bridge, mouth and eyes by using 2 different shades of brown chalk pastels. Scrape a little of the chalk off onto a piece of paper and use a soft paintbrush to pick up the chalk "dust".
steps.visual_description: Two sticks of brown chalk pastel and a soft paintbrush resting on a white surface. Some chalk dust is visible on the surface.

steps.instruction: Now "paint" the dust onto the parts you want to shade.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a needle-felted dog's face, with a paintbrush being used to apply brown chalk dust to the nose bridge, around the eyes, and on the mouth area.

tips: Make sure the dog can sit with front paws touching the ground.
Attach the tail the same way as the ears – between 2 layers of hair.
Trim hair around paws and under mouth if desired.
projects.finished_product_description: A finished needle-felted dog named Drewno, described as bringing warmth and coziness.

projects.name: Dichroic Cabochon Bracelet

steps.instruction: Use a comfortable length of Fireline and thread your needle. I used ±1 m for each bezel. Pick up 36 x 11° Delicas. Knot the Fireline to form a ring, leaving a ±15 cm tail. (This tail will be used to secure your work.) Pull both sides of the Fireline up to form the ring and leave a space equal to 1 bead. Go through 4 Delicas.
Peyote 1 row with Delicas. Step up.

Peyote 4 rows with Delicas. Remember to step up after each row. Peyote 2 rows with 15° Rocailles. **Very important: Pull the thread tight when adding these two rows. These Rocailles are much smaller than the Delicas and these little beads form the "cap" that the cabochon fits into.**
Work the thread up and through the beads to exit at a Delica on the opposite side of the "cap". Fit the cabochon into the cap, holding it in place with your index finger, middle finger and thumb.
steps.visual_description: Cabochon being fitted into a beaded cap

steps.instruction: Peyote 2 rows with 15° Rocailles, pulling tight all the time. Make a half knot to secure your work (I made a few half knots between the beads).
Do not cut the tail pieces off. These will be used to attach the bezels to the tubes.
Repeat the above 13 times so that you have a total of 14 completed bezelled cabochons.
Attach the bezels two – two; now you will have 7 pairs of bezelled cabochons.
steps.visual_description: Bezels attached in pairs

steps.instruction: Create the tubes: Use a comfortable length of Fireline and thread your needle. I used ± 50 m for each tube. Pick up 20 x 11° Delicas. Peyote 12 rows and "zip" the tube closed. Repeat 7 times. You should have a total of 8 tubes. Attach the bezelled cabochons to these tubes, ending with a tube on both ends.
steps.visual_description: Beaded tubes being created and cabochons attached to them

steps.instruction: Attach the clasp and sew away all loose ends.

tips: Very important: Pull the thread tight when adding the two rows of 15° Rocailles.
Do not cut the tail pieces off the bezels; they will be used to attach the bezels to the tubes.
projects.finished_product_description: A bracelet featuring multiple dichroic cabochons bezelled with beads and attached to beaded tubes, with a clasp closure.

diagram_descriptions: Close-up photo of a beaded bracelet with multiple dichroic cabochons, displayed on a mossy branch.

projects.name: Arcos & Crystal bracelet

steps.instruction: Use a comfortable length Fireline and thread the needle.
Pick up 1 x 4 mm Czech crystal, 4 x 15° Rocaille beads, one part of the clasp and 4 x 15° Rocaille beads. Pass the needle through the 4 mm Czech crystal to form a ring.
steps.visual_description: Beads and clasp strung in a circular shape

steps.instruction: Pick up 4 x 15° Rocaille beads, 1 x 4 mm Czech crystal, 1 x 15° Rocaille bead, 1 x Arcos bead (passing the needle through its first hole from bottom to top), 1 x 15° Rocaille bead, 1 x 4 mm Czech crystal and 4 x 15° Rocaille beads. Pass the needle through the Czech crystal picked up in the previous round. Then, pass the needle through all beads of round 1 and round 2. Repeat this process once more to secure the clasp. Exit through the Arcos’ top hole.
Pick up 2 x 15° Rocaille beads, 1 x 11° Rocaille bead and 2 x 15° Rocaille beads. Pass the needle through the last hole of the same Arcos bead.

Pick up 1 x 15° Rocaille bead, 1 x 4 mm Czech crystal, 1 x 15° Rocaille bead, 1 x Arcos bead, 1 x 15° Rocaille bead, 1 x 4 mm Czech crystal, and 1 x 15° Rocaille bead. Pass the needle through the last hole of the previous Arcos bead, as well as the 15° Rocaille bead, 4 mm Czech crystal, and 15° Rocaille bead. Exit through the hole of the Arcos bead just added.
Repeat the sequence starting from Step 4 (marked with an asterisk) until the bracelet is long enough to fit your wrist. Remember to leave a gap for the second part of the clasp.
Add the second part of the clasp, using the same method as the first part. Sew through these beads a few times to secure your work.
Sew away all loose ends.

tips: Keep in mind that you must leave a gap for the second part of the clasp when repeating the pattern.

projects.name: Poppies

steps.instruction: Heavily load your brush with any colour. Now side load with a contrasting colour.
steps.visual_description: Photo showing a brush with yellow paint on one side and red paint on the other, with a dab of red paint next to it.

steps.instruction: Following the series of photos on the next page, roll your brush with the contrasting colour facing outwards, along the edge of the petal. You will see a heavy load of two colours on the edge.
steps.visual_description: Photo showing a brush with yellow and red paint being applied to the edge of a petal.

steps.instruction: Push your brush down into the paint, gently - not too hard.
Push and pull the colours downwards towards the middle.

tips: Practice side loading on a black practice sheet before painting on wood.

projects.name: Painting the Poppies

steps.instruction: Basecoat with blue chalk paint. Leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Rub over the blue paint with the piece of candle.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Paint over with the cream chalk paint. Leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Sand back where you have applied the candle.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Sketch in a basic poppy design or trace the pattern supplied.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Firstly paint in all the petals.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Then stipple in the centres with black using a Deerfoot brush.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Stipple in yellow with touches of white for light.
steps.visual_description: A hand painting a petal with pink paint, showing contrasting color on the edge.

steps.instruction: Thin down the black paint with water then pull out thin pollen streaks in the centre.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a poppy center with thin black lines radiating outwards.

steps.instruction: For the green foliage, I have used a basic comma stroke.
steps.visual_description: Green leaves painted with comma-shaped strokes.

tips: Keep practising until you get it right!
Always pull the colours down towards the stem or the centre of your flower.
Don't be tempted to put in the sun - your wax will melt!

projects.name: Mosaic Rabbits

steps.instruction: Sketch your design and the colours you wish use on a piece of copy paper.
Draw the full scale design on your wooden cut out.
Stick the inserts onto the wood with wood glue.
Using the tile cutters and/or nippers cut the tiles and stick them one by one to the cut out. Remember to first do the design then the background.
Let the glue dry completely.
Mix the grout with water to a smooth paste.
Using a grouting squeegee or old credit card push the grout into all the spaces between the mosaics. Remove as much as possible from the top of the tiles.
Sprinkle some dry grout on the surface and rub off with a piece of scrunched up newspaper.
When the grout is dry, buff the mosaics.
Mix a little grout with some wood glue and smear along the edge of the cut out to finish off the edge.

tips: Hide in the garden!

projects.name: Angel Painting on Denim

materials.item: pieces of quilting fabric for lining
materials.color: your choice of fabric and colour
white, rust, olive green, blue, burnt umber, purple, yellow, flesh and red

tools.name: Saral transfer paper or dressmakers' carbon

steps.instruction: Copy the pattern onto carbon paper then transfer it onto the bull denim rectangle using either Saral transfer paper or dressmakers' carbon.
steps.visual_description: A drawing of an angel's head and wings on a piece of fabric.

steps.instruction: Go over the outline with a permanent pen.
steps.visual_description: The angel drawing from step 1, with the outlines reinforced by a permanent pen.

steps.instruction: Roughly paint in rust just behind the head. Leave some areas unpainted as you want the fabric to show through.
steps.visual_description: The angel drawing with a rust-colored wash applied behind the head, with some fabric showing through.

steps.instruction: While wet, add in some dark green - here and there as you do not want to muddy it. You still want a bit of open area. Let it dry.
steps.visual_description: The angel drawing with rust and dark green paint applied, with areas of unpainted fabric visible.

steps.instruction: When dry, add a bit of extender then blend in some ochre and white. Blend in well - climb in with your fingers if you don't mind a mess! Let dry.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the angel's halo area, showing blending of ochre and white paint with extender.

steps.instruction: Paint the top of the halo with white, blending in a tiny bit of ochre and green (just a very little bit).
steps.visual_description: The top section of the angel's halo painted white with subtle hints of ochre and green.

steps.instruction: Mix some white and extender into the ochre and paint in bottom of the halo and top of wings.
steps.visual_description: The bottom of the angel's halo and the top of the wings painted with a mixture of ochre, white, and extender.

steps.instruction: Now basecoat the rest of the picture. The bottom of the wings with some light purple, the face with flesh, the hair with burnt umber diluted with extender otherwise it is too dark. Leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: The angel's wings, face, and hair are base coated in light purple, flesh, and diluted burnt umber respectively.

steps.instruction: Start streaking in white in the hair, and white on the face. A little bit of lightened blue lightly applied to the eyelids and under the chin. Colour in the heart and lips with dark pink. Lighten some pink and brush in on the cheeks and a bit on the forehead. Continue adding in more white on dress and wings. Let dry.
steps.visual_description: A painting of an angel with white highlights in the hair and face, light blue on eyelids and chin, dark pink heart and lips, and pink on cheeks and forehead. More white is added to the dress and wings.

steps.instruction: Apply some gel medium to the lower wings. If you are using the top layer of a
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the angel's lower wings, with gel medium being applied.

tips: Test fine, black permanent pen on fabric first to make sure it doesn't bleed.
Place small dollops of paint and extender on clingwrap plate to mix colors without a mess.
Blend well, using fingers if necessary.
projects.finished_product_description: A painted angel on a denim background.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the initial transfer of an angel pattern onto fabric.
Close-up of the angel's halo area showing paint blending.
Close-up of the angel's face and upper body showing painted details.
Close-up of the angel's lower wings with gel medium being applied.

projects.name: The bag

steps.instruction: From the denim fabric cut: (2) 12½" x 4" strips, (1) 12¼" x 15½" and (2) 4" x 30".
Attach the (2) 12½" x 4" strips to either side of the painted picture. Press seams towards picture. Top stitch down seam. Trim piece to 12¼" x 15½".
steps.visual_description: Painted picture with two denim strips attached to its sides.

steps.instruction: From all four pieces (denim and lining pieces), on the bottom edge, cut a 1¼" square from both sides.
steps.visual_description: Four fabric pieces with a square cut from each bottom corner.

steps.instruction: Join the two denim pieces along the bottom using a ¼" seam allowance. Press the seam open.
steps.visual_description: Two denim pieces joined at the bottom edge.

steps.instruction: Join the sides. Press the seam open.
Fold and press a small hem on each end of both straps (4" x 30"). Stitch in place.
steps.visual_description: Two fabric straps with a hemmed edge on each end.

steps.instruction: Fold in half lengthwise, wrong sides together. Stitch down the length. Turn right side out and press.
Pin to front and back of denim piece. Make sure that they are not twisted. Baste in place to top of bag.
Apply gold or bronze rub on to your fingertips and rub on bottom part of halo and on some areas on the top of the wings. Use the photo alongside as a guide.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of an angel's halo and wings with gold/bronze rub applied.

steps.instruction: Outline the halo and top of wings with a thin line of gold liner. Draw in the lines on the wings with a thin line of liner. Let dry before moving to next step.
steps.visual_description: Angel's halo and wings with gold liner outlines and wing details.

steps.instruction: Dilute burnt umber with some extender and shade in around the heart, shoulders and under chin.
steps.visual_description: Angel painting with burnt umber shading around the heart, shoulders, and chin.

steps.instruction: Mix a bit of blue with burnt umber to get a really dark blue and shade in on the hair. Add in "v" for arms. Using the fineliner and same paint, write in the word "Love". Leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: Angel painting with dark blue hair shading, 'v' shaped arms, and the word 'Love' written on the chest.

steps.instruction: Using the Pigma micron pen go over the lips, eyes and nose.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the angel's face with lips, eyes, and nose outlined with a Pigma micron pen.

steps.instruction: Lastly add in some more white onto the hair. Leave to dry. Then trim to 9"x 12½".
steps.visual_description: Angel painting with added white highlights in the hair, trimmed to size.

tips: You could write a special message along the top of the halo if you wish.
projects.finished_product_description: A mixed media angel painting incorporated into a denim bag.

diagram_descriptions: A painting of an angel with a large red heart on its chest, wings, and a halo. The word 'LOVE' is written on the heart.
A close-up of the angel painting, showing the face with closed eyes, pink lips, and a detailed halo.
A denim bag being constructed, showing the painted angel picture attached to the front panel and the straps being prepared.

projects.name: Denim Bag

steps.instruction: With both the lining and denim bag wrong sides out, bring the bottom seam up to the side seam and match the two seams. Sew across the join to form a box base.
steps.visual_description: Photo showing the bottom seam of a bag being aligned with the side seam to form a box base.

steps.instruction: Place the denim bag inside the lining, right sides together. Make sure that the seams butt nicely together then pin all around the top. Make sure that the straps are facing down and out of the way.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the denim bag placed inside the lining bag, with right sides together and seams aligned at the top. Straps are shown facing down and out of the way.

steps.instruction: Stitch all the way around using a ½" seam allowance.
Pull the denim bag through the opening at the bottom. Insert your hand into the opening and push out the corners on the denim bag.
Close the opening in the lining. Push the lining back down into the denim bag.
Roll the edges with your fingers so that they lay nice and flat then press well - use some steam to set them.
Keeping the straps out of the way, top stitch all around the top.

Hold the bottom edge of the box seam and the top edge next to the handle, finger press a fold down the length. Edge stitch down from the top to the side of the box seam. Do this on all four sides. This will give the bag a bit more stability.
steps.visual_description: Photo showing the bottom edge of the box seam and the top edge next to the handle being finger pressed to create a fold. The instruction indicates to edge stitch down from the top to the side of the box seam on all four sides.

tips: To finish off the bag you can choose to have a press stud attached (some Bernina stores do this) or leave as is.
projects.finished_product_description: A handmade denim bag with a lining, featuring a decorative design on the outer denim panel and straps.

materials.notes: Joined together and sanded very smooth. Can be found from Hannes and Ronel Pieterse or at CTM stores.
Outdoor paint. Colors used were Tango blue.
Specific color of Americana patio paint used.

projects.name: Angels Protecting

steps.instruction: Prime the wood first. Because the primer is white the pencil will stand out better. Sketch in the figure shapes as well as the houses and church in the background with a pencil. Use a fineliner and brown paint to outline the design.
steps.visual_description: A pencil sketch on wood of figures, houses, and a church in the background.

steps.instruction: Paint in the night sky with black, tango blue and white. Streak in white clouds with a flat brush. Paint in the mountain range in the background with pansy purple. Add white for the bright, starry night reflections. Now start painting in your little town. Yellow windows are light reflections to show that people really live there (of course) and the angels are protecting them.
steps.visual_description: A night sky with blue and white streaks, a purple mountain range, and a town with yellow windows. Figures of people and angels are present.

steps.instruction: Paint in the tree with a mixture of brown, black and grey. Start painting in the fields, starting in the far background with a deeper, darker colour and moving closer with lighter colours. Remember your colour perspective when doing this: farther - darker, nearer - lighter!
steps.visual_description: A tree is painted with brown, black, and grey. Fields are painted with darker colors in the background and lighter colors in the foreground.

tips: Remember your colour perspective when doing this: farther - darker, nearer - lighter!
projects.finished_product_description: A painting on wood depicting figures, possibly angels, in a landscape with a night sky, mountains, a town, and a tree.

The top row shows three images: a close-up of a painted sky with figures, a painting of figures with houses in the background, and a painting of a figure with houses in the background. The bottom row shows three images: a pencil sketch of figures and houses, a painting of a blue and purple landscape with houses, and a painting of figures under a tree with houses in the background.

A list of paint colors: Wrought iron black, Grey skies, Cloud white, Pansy purple, Fiesta yellow, Geranium red, Desert turquoise, Woodland brown, Carnation pink, Fuchsia pink, Azalea pink, Rich espresso.

projects.name: Angel Painting

steps.instruction: Sketch in more details on the angels now. I must say - mine changed their hair colour, hair band and flowers several times!
steps.visual_description: Close-up of angels' faces and hair details.

steps.instruction: For the dresses I used the three different pinks, bronze, cream and white. I absolutely love the bronze colour. You will notice I also used it on the wings!
steps.visual_description: Angels' dresses in various colors, including bronze on wings.

steps.instruction: Underpaint the hearts being sprinkled onto the little angels with yellow and then paint over with red.
steps.visual_description: Hearts on angels are underpainted yellow and then painted red.

steps.instruction: I used a dot maker to dot in the stars but you can also use the back of a paintbrush. My music notes resemble leaves.
steps.visual_description: Stars are dotted onto the blue background, resembling musical notes.

tips: Just a reminder - do not expose your masterpiece to moisture for 72 hours.

projects.name: A Modern, Marbled Side Table
projects.finished_product_description: A side table with a marbled effect achieved using acrylic pouring techniques.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up shot of a round side table with a dark blue and white marbled top, created using acrylic pouring. A crystal vase filled with white roses is placed on the table. To the left, a basket overflows with artificial lavender and greenery.

projects.name: Marble Slick Pour Table Top

steps.instruction: For the best results mix your paints 24 hours before pouring. It will allow resting time for the products to develop and air bubbles to surface.

Pour all of the navy fabric paint into one of the empty containers. Add in an equal amount of pouring glaze. Mix well - you want a smooth consistency. Add ± 50 ml of water, a little at a time, to give you a "warm honey" consistency.
Repeat with the maroon fabric paint and white craft paint.
Spray 18 - 20 spritz of marble slick into the navy container and mix well.
Spray 16 - 18 spritz of marble slick into the maroon container and mix well (just a little bit less than that you added into the navy container).
Pour a little of each colour into the remaining empty container, repeating the sequence of colours till the container is half full.
Put the round disc on top of the container and flip it over keeping the cup in place.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a cup filled with paint, placing it upside down on a round disc.

steps.instruction: Pour white paint around the base of the still upside down cup, repeat with the navy and maroon paint.
Using a "swirling" motion, lift the cup slightly to release a tiny bit of paint at a time. (You don't want to flood the disc.)
steps.visual_description: A hand lifting an upside down cup from a disc, allowing paint to flow out in a swirling pattern.

steps.instruction: Tilt the disc so the paint can run across the whole surface area and down the sides (DO NOT TILT TO MUCH!). Put aside for 24 hours to set.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of paint flowing across a disc and down the sides.

steps.instruction: Paint the inside of each utensil holder.
Using craft glue, join the two open ends to form the base of the table.
Paint the base with the navy craft paint. Once the disc has dried, apply a coat of spray on varnish to seal the surface.
Paint the back of the disc and touch up the rim.
Join the base and the disc with craft glue.
Apply another coat of spray on varnish. Let dry and your table is finished.

tips: It's a good idea to alternate the amounts of marble slick added to each paint colour.
Metallic slick is not suitable for metallic paint. Not adding marble slick to the white mixture is a personal preference.
projects.finished_product_description: A table with a marbelized, poured paint finish on the top surface.

projects.name: Sharn Rug

materials.item: sheet yarn (sheets, pillowcases or fabric cut into strips)

tools.name: crochet hook
tools.purpose: to crochet the yarn and rope

steps.instruction: Cut sheets, pillowcases or fabric into strips to create 'yarn'.
Crochet the 'yarn' together with thin rope to create a bathroom rug.
steps.visual_description: An oval-shaped rug made of crocheted strips of fabric in various colors (pink, yellow, blue, white, purple) with a light blue border.

tips: The rope gives stability to the rug.
This recycling technique can also be used on plastic bags (plarn) and T-shirting (tarn).
projects.finished_product_description: A handmade oval rug created by crocheting fabric strips and thin rope together. The rug features a colorful, textured pattern with a light blue border.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up photo of a handmade oval rug with a colorful, textured pattern made from crocheted fabric strips and a light blue border. A potted plant sits on the rug.
The text 'Recycle, -Re-use.!' is written in a white, cursive font across the top of the image.
The title 'Sharn Rug' is written in a large, yellow, sans-serif font.

The text 'by Sharon Calverley' is written in a small, dark font in the bottom right corner.

projects.name: Ball of Sharn Rug

steps.instruction: Fold fabric in half lengthwise, right sides together. Reduce your stitch size then stitch the open ends together. You will now have formed a tube with a seam on one end.
Place the fabric on your rug. Bring the bottom half up towards the seamed edge, making sure that it is ± 4" down from the seamed edge.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing a piece of fabric on a grid rug. The bottom half of the fabric is folded up towards the top edge, with an arrow indicating a 4 inch measurement from the top edge of the folded section to the seamed edge.

steps.instruction: Align the bottom edge with a line on the rug then trim the sides so that they are neat.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing a piece of fabric on a grid rug. The bottom edge is aligned with a line on the rug, and the sides are being trimmed. A dashed line indicates the fold line at the top.

steps.instruction: Working from the left hand side, cut a 1" wide strip from the bottom edge up till just past the fold line at the top. Don't cut all the way through to the top edge!
Move the ruler 1" to the right and cut the next strip. Continue doing this until you reach the right hand side. If you have a little bit extra left over on the right hand

Lift fabric up from rug. At this stage it looks a bit strange, but don't worry! Open up the two layers. The easiest way is to insert your arm so that the fabric drapes over your arm and the seam lays along the top of your arm.
steps.visual_description: A photo showing a piece of fabric that has been cut into strips, being lifted up and draped over an arm.

steps.instruction: Using a scissors, cut from the outside edge, just above the seam line, to the first cut. See photo below. Let the strip fall free.
steps.visual_description: A photo showing scissors cutting a strip of fabric from the outside edge, just above a seam line, following a previous cut. The strip is falling free.

steps.instruction: Your next cut is diagonally from the bottom section, below the seam up to the cut in the top section above the seam. See
For the last piece, cut from the bottom to the outside edge, under the seam allowance.
steps.visual_description: A photo showing the final cut being made on a strip of fabric, from the bottom to the outside edge, under the seam allowance.

tips: If you are re-cycling a pillowcase, you can join pieces to make up a workable length i.e. 1.5 m.
Make sure that when you join lengths end to end, you stitch a double row of stitching so that the join is really strong. Press seams to one side.
projects.finished_product_description: A rug made from strips of fabric rolled into balls (sharn).

diagram_descriptions: A photo showing multiple strips of fabric being cut diagonally from bottom to top, with the strips falling free.
A photo showing a close-up of fabric being cut with scissors, following a previous cut line.
A photo showing the final cut being made on a strip of fabric, from the bottom to the outside edge, under the seam allowance.

projects.name: Rag Rug

steps.instruction: Starting approximately 8" in from the end of the rope, begin winding the fabric strips diagonally around the rope. Place a peg/bulldog clip at the beginning, adding one every now and then to prevent the fabric unravelling. Continue right to the end of the rope, placing another peg/bulldog clip there to keep the sharn in place.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows fabric strips being wound around a rope. A black bulldog clip is securing the end of the fabric strips to the rope.

steps.instruction: Make a slip knot at the end, pulling it up so that it fits around the crochet hook.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows a slip knot made with fabric strips, positioned to fit around a crochet hook.

steps.instruction: Holding the fabric loosely, bring the hook under the covered rope and grab the fabric and bring it to the front. You will have two loops on the hook. The first two stitches are a bit tricky, but persevere, it does work!
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows a crochet hook under a rope covered with fabric strips, about to grab a fabric strip to pull it through.

steps.instruction: Yarn around needle then pull through both loops. Make sure that you keep a loose tension otherwise it will pull up skew. You have now made a dc.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows a crochet hook with two loops of fabric on it, with a third loop of fabric being pulled through. A rope is visible underneath the crochet work.

steps.instruction: Continue making these dc's up to the start of the covered rope, where the first peg/bulldog clip is. I managed to fit 15 along the length - if you have more or less don't worry too much as it doesn't affect the pattern.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows a crochet hook working with fabric strips around a rope. The crochet work is progressing along the rope.

steps.instruction: Twist the piece so that the rope is now laying along the bottom of the stitches. Place a peg/bulldog clip a little bit further down to keep the rope in place.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows the crochet work with the rope positioned along the bottom of the stitches. A bulldog clip is used to secure the rope.

steps.instruction: Make 4dc in space created by rope. This is so that you create a curve around the edge. Pull the rope flat against the stitches. Using your fingers, open the space between the dc's slightly then make 1dc in each space to end of row.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows crochet stitches being made around the rope to create a curve. The rope is pulled flat against the stitches.

steps.instruction: When you get to the end of the row make 4dc (cluster dc) into the slip knot hole. Continue to end of row making a dc in each hole then 4dc in the centre of the 4dc's. These 4dc's on either end of the oval will create your curve.
steps.visual_description: A close-up image shows the end of a row of crochet work. The instructions describe making 4dc (cluster dc) into the slip knot hole and then continuing with dc stitches.

tips: Normally rag rugs do not contain rope. I am using rope in the centre section because I wanted a heavier, firmer rug.
projects.finished_product_description: A heavy, firm rag rug made with fabric strips and rope.

diagram_descriptions: A large image shows a pile of fabric strips in various colors (blue, yellow, pink, green, white) wound into balls, suggesting materials for the project.
A close-up image shows fabric strips being wound around a rope, secured with a bulldog clip.
A close-up image shows a slip knot made with fabric strips, ready to be placed on a crochet hook.
A close-up image shows a crochet hook under a rope covered with fabric strips, about to grab a fabric strip to pull it through.
A close-up image shows a crochet hook with two loops of fabric on it, with a third loop of fabric being pulled through. A rope is visible underneath the crochet work.
A close-up image shows a crochet hook working with fabric strips around a rope. The crochet work is progressing along the rope.
A close-up image shows the crochet work with the rope positioned along the bottom of the stitches. A bulldog clip is used to secure the rope.
A close-up image shows crochet stitches being made around the rope to create a curve. The rope is pulled flat against the stitches.
A close-up image shows the end of a row of crochet work. The instructions describe making 4dc (cluster dc) into the slip knot hole and then continuing with dc stitches.

projects.name: Plarn Rug

steps.instruction: Lay the bag flat and cut off both ends.
steps.visual_description: Three rectangular pieces of plastic bag, two are red and one is white with red text. The red pieces are cut from the ends of the bag.

steps.instruction: Fold the bottom up to ± 1½" from the top.
steps.visual_description: A red plastic bag piece is shown folded. The bottom edge is folded up approximately 1.5 inches from the top edge. An arrow indicates the fold.

steps.instruction: Following the same instructions for making sharn (steps 2-9) cut up into one long length. It's easier to use a sharp pair of scissors here.
Roll up and put to one side till you have enough to turn into a shopping bag or rug. Keep in mind that you will have to attach some anti-slip material to the bottom of the rug.

As your oval gets bigger you will have to increase the size of your curve. There is no exact science to this, you will be guided by the feel of the curve i.e. by adding an extra dc into a stitch if you feel the stitch has not enough ease to go into the next hole and feels a bit tight. As soon as you have to make a stitch "lean" over to get into the next stitch you will find the piece begin to pull - and you don't want that!
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a crochet hook working with colorful strips of fabric or plastic, creating a textured stitch.

steps.instruction: The trick is to lay the rug flat every now and then. If you see it is pulling up slightly - add an extra stitch or two on the curve. If it is loose (a bit like lettuce) don't add a stitch on that side till a row or two later. Never, ever add a stitch on the straight edge - only on the curve!
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a crocheted rug with a colorful, textured pattern. The rug is oval-shaped and appears to be made from strips of fabric or plastic.

steps.instruction: Continue crocheting around the oval until it measures ± 27"x 16½", making sure that the rope is encapsulated in each stitch - it's very easy to crochet away and find that you forgot all about the rope a few rows back!
When you reach the size mentioned in step 9, simply cut the rope. Continue crocheting around the oval till you reach the finished size you want.
Pull the sharn through the stitch to knot it then using a long tail and the knitters' needle, hiding the tail back in the stitches.
Steam press the finished item and it's ready for use.

tips: If you need to join sharn strips, simply knot together (leaving a long tail) and continue. You can work them away later with a knitters' needle.
projects.finished_product_description: These plarn rugs are great to donate to animal or homeless shelters.

projects.name: Upcycled Chair Planter
projects.finished_product_description: A chair planter is a creative and easy-to-make decoration that can liven up any patio or quiet corner. It doesn’t require much in terms of tools, and the task is straightforward.

diagram_descriptions: A young person smiling and leaning on a wooden chair that has been converted into a planter. A basket filled with soil and red flowers sits in the seat of the chair.

projects.name: Upcycled Chair Planter

materials.details: Wooden chair is preferred, but any chair that is not being used and is slightly weathered or damaged is perfect.
With hooks and chains removed. A wire basket can also be used.
Choose plants suitable for the intended location (sun or shade).

tools.name: Staple gun
tools.purpose: To attach the seat to the chair (implied for removal)

steps.instruction: Remove the seat of the chair. Be careful not to damage the rest of the chair.
steps.visual_description: A wooden chair with its seat removed, showing the structure of the chair.

steps.instruction: Fill the hanging basket with potting soil, keeping it only semi-full. This ensures there is enough space to plant the flowers and that their roots are comfortable and supported.
steps.visual_description: Hands filling a hanging basket with potting soil, leaving some space at the top.

steps.instruction: Gently place the plants in the hanging basket, covering the roots with soil and pressing the soil down to ensure the plant is well supported. If there isn't enough space for the amount of soil needed, a larger basket might be required.
steps.visual_description: Hands planting flowers into a hanging basket filled with soil.

steps.instruction: Give the plant a good amount of water, ensuring the soil is properly soaked. Place the basket into the chair, filling the seating area with beautiful flowers.
steps.visual_description: A hanging basket filled with red impatiens flowers placed into the seat area of an upcycled wooden chair.

tips: Remember to give your flowers the right amount of water, and a little bit of sunlight every day.
projects.finished_product_description: An upcycled wooden chair used as a planter, with a hanging basket filled with flowers placed in the seat area.

projects.name: Reflections of a Happy Home

steps.instruction: Start by painting the wooden blank in the desired colour.

Plan the layout by first arranging all the items onto the wooden blank. Make soft pencil marks for use later. (Taking a reference photo with your cell phone is a great way to remember where everything must go!)
Paste the mirror down using silicone mirror glue.
Tack the design and word stencils in place with masking tape.
Apply texture / Qualitex paste over the stencils to create a raised surface. Carefully remove the stencils immediately once stencilled.
Once the texture paste is completely dry and hard, roughly paint in foliage in the background.
Place the vase where you want it and glue it down.
Paste evenly spaced white tiles around the top corners of the canvas.
steps.visual_description: White tiles placed around the top corners of the canvas.

steps.instruction: Glue the flowers down. You will not have to grout this project, so that is it - all done!

tips: Remember to let everyone sign the back of the canvas and don't forget the date!

projects.name: Butterfly Garden Glass Art
projects.finished_product_description: A stained glass butterfly garden art piece.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up photo of a stained glass butterfly garden art piece, featuring iridescent blue and purple glass for the wings, with white glass accents. The butterfly is framed by a square border made of textured green glass. The piece is mounted on a thin metal stake and is set against a blurred background of bamboo stalks and green foliage.

projects.name: Butterfly Suncatcher

materials.item: Quick drying two part epoxy glue

tools.name: Dishwash liquid and Bicarbonate of Soda solution

steps.instruction: I made the butterfly first. Make sure you have two numbered copies of the template. Cut one out to use as pattern pieces to cut your glass. Leave the other whole to use as a template at the grinder. Placing the pattern piece upside down on the wrong side of the glass (smoother side), draw around each piece with a permanent marker/sharpie. Remember to number each piece with the same number that appears on the pattern piece.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a blue glass piece and drawing a butterfly wing shape with a black Sharpie pen. The glass has a blue marbled pattern. A white paper template is partially visible on top of the glass.

steps.instruction: Score the glass with the cutter. Use a running pliers and/or grozier pliers to break where you have scored.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a glass cutter and scoring a piece of blue glass. The glass piece is shaped like a butterfly wing and has a number '10' marked on it. Another hand is holding grozier pliers near the scored line.

steps.instruction: Grind the pieces so that they fit onto the template. Use map pins to hold each piece in place once you have finished grinding it, so that it does not move around while you are working on the other pieces. The general rule is that you should be able to see the black line of the template around each piece of glass. They must fit accurately and snugly together.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding grozier pliers to break a scored piece of blue glass. The glass piece is shaped like a butterfly wing and has a number '10' marked on it. The scored line is visible.

tips: The general rule is that you should be able to see the black line of the template around each piece of glass. They must fit accurately and snugly together.
projects.finished_product_description: A stained glass butterfly suncatcher with blue and purple glass pieces, framed with copper foil and solder.

templates.name: Butterfly Template
templates.shape_description: A template for cutting glass pieces for a butterfly. It includes numbered sections for different parts of the butterfly.

diagram_descriptions: A finished stained glass butterfly suncatcher with purple and blue glass pieces, set against a background of green foliage.
A hand marking a blue glass piece with a black marker to trace a butterfly wing pattern from a paper template.
A hand scoring a blue glass piece with a glass cutter, with grozier pliers nearby to break the glass along the score line.
A hand using grozier pliers to break a scored piece of blue glass.

projects.name: Stained Glass Butterfly

steps.instruction: Once you have finished grinding, begin foiling each of the pieces with 1/4 inch foil. It is important that the pieces are all clean and thoroughly dry. So clean and dry them off with a soft cloth before you begin to foil. It's much easier to work upside down. You need to get the glass in the centre of the foil. Hold the sticky side facing up and place the glass onto it. Press flat with your thumb then fold down over the sides of the glass. Work in small sections to ensure that the foil fits tightly once you are done. Try not to go all the way around your glass piece and then only flatten the foil, as it will be too loose. Iron out the creases and crinkles in the foil with the lathekin.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of blue glass and applying copper foil tape to its edges. The foil is being pressed flat and folded over the sides of the glass. Another image shows hands using a tool (lathekin) to smooth out creases in the foil.

steps.instruction: Place the pieces back in their place on the template as you go. Once they are all foiled you can solder the butterfly together. Flux all the seams and melt blobs of solder along each seam. Melt these blobs into each seam connecting the pieces securely. Repeat the process on the other side.
steps.visual_description: A stained glass butterfly pattern on a template with some blue glass pieces placed on it. A soldering iron is shown melting solder along the seams of the glass pieces.

steps.instruction: Tin around all the edges of the butterfly. All of the foiling must be silver after this.

Now cut the frame for the butterfly from the clear Krinkle glass. I didn't use a template. I simply measured. Each frame side is 3 cm wide. Mine are 20 cm each in length, but lay the butterfly on some paper or board and make sure that your frame will meet up and touch the butterfly in certain places so that you can solder the butterfly to the frame.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of blue glass and a tool, possibly a glass cutter, to shape it. The glass piece is a wing of the butterfly.

steps.instruction: Gently grind around each section of the frame, just to make the edges rough so that the foil sticks to it. Foil each of the border pieces. I used a set square to make sure the corners of the frame were at right angles.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of glass against a grinding tool. The edges of the glass are being ground.

steps.instruction: Solder the corners together and tin around all the edges of your frame. Lay it flat and place the butterfly in position to solder it permanently into place. Spot solder the butterfly where it touches the frame. Make sure the bottom of the body is soldered securely to the bottom of the frame. This will bring greater stability. Cut lengths of brazing rod (copper rod) and solder them in place. I bent them slightly so that they were curved. Solder them to the butterfly's head and onto the frame. Rinse off the butterfly and the frame with the soapy solution and dry thoroughly.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a stained glass frame being soldered. The corners are joined, and a soldering iron is shown applying solder. Another image shows a stained glass butterfly being soldered onto the frame. Copper rods are being used to attach parts of the butterfly to the frame.

steps.instruction: I purchased fairly long pieces of steel pipe and cut it to size. This is a personal choice and you will need to decide how high you want your framed butterfly to stand off the ground once you have pushed the rod into the ground. Give the rod a good sand to enable the solder to stick.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a metal rod being prepared, possibly for a stand. The rod is being sanded.

tips: It's much easier to work upside down when foiling.
Work in small sections to ensure that the foil fits tightly.
Iron out the creases and crinkles in the foil with the lathekin.
Make sure the bottom of the body is soldered securely to the bottom of the frame for greater stability.
Bend the brazing rod slightly so that they were curved.
Give the rod a good sand to enable the solder to stick.
projects.finished_product_description: A stained glass butterfly mounted on a frame, which can stand off the ground.

A close-up of a stained glass frame being soldered at the corners.
A close-up of a stained glass butterfly being soldered onto its frame.
A close-up of a metal rod being sanded, likely for a stand.

projects.name: Stained Glass Butterfly

tools.name: safety specs
tools.purpose: eye protection during cutting and grinding

steps.instruction: Turn the butterfly over so that the wrong side is facing upwards and spot solder the rod into place along the back of your butterfly panel. I soldered mine at the top, near the middle and at the bottom.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a stained glass butterfly panel with copper foil edges. A soldering iron is being used to attach a copper rod to the back of the panel at the top, middle, and bottom.

steps.instruction: Spray some soapy solution onto where you have soldered the rod to the panel and clean off gently.
Patina the butterfly and frame with copper patina, then rinse it off. Mix some of the glue and stick the glass gems in place wherever you want them on your butterfly.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a stained glass butterfly panel. Hands wearing white gloves are applying glue to the panel and placing small blue glass gems onto it.

steps.instruction: I sprayed the rod with the anti-rust spray in a brown. You will need to cover the stained glass panel as you don't want to get any of the spray on the glass. I used newspaper as a mask. Spray both sides of the rod, covering the glass each time. Wait for the one side to dry before turning over to spray the other side.
Once the spray has dried, use some furniture polish spray and a soft cloth to shine the piece. This really brings out the colour of the glass as well as the patina on the joins, sides and edges.
Find a place in your garden where it will be easily visible and catch the light.
steps.visual_description: A finished stained glass butterfly panel hanging outdoors, with green foliage in the background.

tips: While soldering small blobs of solder will end up on your board. I use a metal ruler to brush them off. NB – They may still be hot. I also collect them in a small container and use them for tinning other projects. Great cost saver and they are perfectly good to use for tinning on your next project.
While you are not using your soldering iron, remember to keep it on its stand to avoid burning yourself or anything around you.
Always wear safety specs while cutting and grinding. I wear specs for close up work which provides adequate eye protection.
While grinding wear an apron as tiny pieces of glass can stick to your clothing and later you will brush yourself off with your hands, which you want to avoid doing.

You can use a small scoop and brush to regularly clear your work surface of small shards of glass. If you cut a new piece of glass and press down on small pieces that have accumulated on the board, you run the risk of cracking the glass while scoring it. Don't sweep the surface off with your hand as small pieces of glass are difficult to remove from your fingers and hands.
You can also simply cover your cutting board with newspaper and fold all the bits into the newspaper, dump it in the bin and place clean newspaper down on your board.
projects.finished_product_description: A stained glass butterfly panel with blue and brown glass, framed with copper foil and solder, displayed outdoors.

diagram_descriptions: Close-up of a stained glass butterfly panel with copper foil edges. A soldering iron is being used to attach a copper rod to the back of the panel at the top, middle, and bottom.
Close-up of a stained glass butterfly panel. Hands wearing white gloves are applying glue to the panel and placing small blue glass gems onto it.
A finished stained glass butterfly panel hanging outdoors, with green foliage in the background.

projects.name: Lino Block Design

steps.instruction: Start with a French curve and pick out some sweeping shapes.
steps.visual_description: A blue French curve tool is placed on a grey surface with faint circular and curved line guides.

steps.instruction: Fill in the spaces around the sweeping shapes.
steps.visual_description: A grey surface with faint circular and curved line guides, with some areas filled in with white lines creating a pattern.

steps.instruction: Create more focal points along the edges and add small focal points in the corners.
steps.visual_description: A grey surface with faint circular and curved line guides, with white lines forming a complex, symmetrical pattern with focal points along the edges and in the corners.

steps.instruction: Neatly clean out all the spaces in between the drawn lines.
steps.visual_description: A lino block stamp design with intricate white lines on a grey background, showing a symmetrical pattern with many small, clean spaces.

tips: When you have focal points along the edge of a stamp like this, the focal point will straddle two stamps on the repetition. This will help to blur the hard rectangular edge of the stamp, as the eye is drawn to the dominating lines and focal point instead.

I look forward to seeing how it prints on cloth. If you’d like to see some of the fabrics that I will be printing over the months that follow using this stamp, then join the Up-Cycled Cloth Collective on Facebook. For more of my secrets for creating interlinking stamps for printing on cloth, send me an email with the words: “I want to learn the secrets of tiled prints” in the tagline and I will send you a complimentary eBook that shares detailed step-by-step tutorials with pictures.
projects.finished_product_description: Tiled stamps for printing on cloth with repeating swirling patterns.

A grey surface with faint circular and curved line guides, with some areas filled in with white lines creating a pattern, illustrating the development of the design.

A grey surface with faint circular and curved line guides, with white lines forming a complex, symmetrical pattern with focal points along the edges and in the corners, showing the design with added focal points.
A lino block stamp design with intricate white lines on a grey background, showing a symmetrical pattern with many small, clean spaces, representing the cleaned-out design.

A series of images showing the progression of a lino block stamp design. The first image shows a blue French curve tool on a background with faint geometric lines. Subsequent images show the design evolving with white lines, becoming more intricate and symmetrical, culminating in a detailed, repeating pattern.

A close-up of a lino block stamp design featuring a symmetrical, intricate pattern of white lines on a grey background. The pattern resembles stylized floral or fan shapes arranged in a repeating, tessellating manner.

projects.name: Red Hearts Lino Printing

steps.instruction: Line the table with an old printing blanket. It not only catches spills and messes, it also creates a padded surface for printing. The soft padding allows some give so that all of the surfaces of the stamp make contact with the fabric so that the paint is properly transferred. If you try to print on a rigid surface, you will struggle to get the prints to transfer properly.

Use the pallet knife to scoop paint onto the plastic lid and coat the sponge roller with an even coating of paint. Use the spray bottle with water to keep the paint on the paint tray moist. If you are printing in hot dry weather, the spray bottle is a life saver. A gentle spritz of water will prevent the acrylic paint from making a skin on the surface.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a red sponge roller being dipped into red paint in a clear plastic lid.

steps.instruction: Use a very light touch with the sponge roller. Do not press down onto the sponge, rather allow the wheel to run gently under the pressure of gravity while you push forward. This light touch will give you a thin, even coating of paint on the stamp. If you have big globs of paint on the stamp, they will create big ugly marks on the prints. The idea is to coat the stamp with a thin, even layer of paint for even prints.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a red sponge roller being used to apply paint to a lino stamp with a geometric pattern. The stamp is on a surface with other printed patterns.

tips: A gentle spritz of water will prevent the acrylic paint from making a skin on the surface.
If you are printing in hot dry weather, the spray bottle is a life saver.
projects.finished_product_description: A red scarf with a white geometric lino print pattern.

diagram_descriptions: Close-up of a red sponge roller being dipped into red paint in a clear plastic lid.
Close-up of a red sponge roller being used to apply paint to a lino stamp with a geometric pattern. The stamp is on a surface with other printed patterns.

projects.name: Tiled Fabric Printing

steps.instruction: Iron the fabric perfectly smooth before you begin.
Place the stamp carefully, ink side down, onto the corner of the fabric.
steps.visual_description: A stamp with ink on its surface is placed onto the corner of a piece of fabric.

steps.instruction: Run the rubber roller over the back of the stamp to apply pressure that would transfer the paint from stamp to cloth.
steps.visual_description: A rubber roller is being used on the back of a stamp that is on fabric.

steps.instruction: Peel the stamp carefully away to reveal the first print.
steps.visual_description: A stamp is being peeled away from fabric, revealing a printed design.

steps.instruction: Repeat the process to cover the fabric, row by row.
steps.visual_description: Multiple rows of stamped patterns are visible on the fabric.

steps.instruction: Iron the fabric at 140° Celsius for six minutes, as recommended by the supplier, so that the print is wash fast.

tips: Ironing the fabric before starting helps to remove creases, which can leave marks on the print.

If you want to learn more secrets for creating interlinking stamps for printing on cloth, send an email to info@dyeandprints.co.za with the subject 'I want to learn the secrets of tiled prints' to receive a complimentary eBook.

projects.name: Mosaic Mirror
tips: Use up tile off cuts and unused inserts
projects.finished_product_description: A mosaic-decorated mirror with various colorful tiles and inserts including hearts, flowers, ladybugs, a dragonfly, a frog, a face, and the words 'Joy', 'Love', and 'Peace'.

diagram_descriptions: A circular mirror decorated with a mosaic of colorful tiles and various decorative inserts. The mosaic includes patterns of yellow and red tiles, purple tiles, green tiles, and red tiles. Decorative elements include red hearts (some with white speckles), a red heart with wings, a white dove, the word 'Love' in a white rectangle, yellow flowers with black dots, white flowers with red dots, a blue flower center, a dragonfly, a frog, ladybugs, a face with brown hair, a green swirl, a pink flower, a yellow flower, and small glass beads in blue, purple, and green. The words 'Joy' and 'Peace' are also visible as mosaic elements.

projects.name: Mirror, Mirror on the Wall

materials.item: Variety of tiles and inserts, glass pebbles and even beads

steps.instruction: Glue all the inserts in place all over the wooden frame. Group some together and some standing on their own.
steps.visual_description: A wooden frame with a mirror in the center, partially covered with various mosaic inserts like hearts, flowers, and dots. Some inserts are placed flat, while others stand slightly raised.

steps.instruction: Divide the background into random blocks with a pencil. This is just a guideline. Sort the mosaics according to colour combinations that you love and mosaic the background.
steps.visual_description: The wooden frame is now more filled with mosaic pieces. Faint pencil lines are visible, dividing the background into irregular sections. The mosaic pieces are sorted by color and arranged to fill the background.

steps.instruction: When finished the mosaic, leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: The mosaic on the wooden frame is complete and appears to be drying.

steps.instruction: Mix the grout as per manufacturer’s instructions. You need to be able to pour the grout onto the mosaic if you used ceramic tiles. For glass tiles try a toothpaste consistency.

Work the grout over the tiles with a rubber kidney, old credit card or your hand, making sure the grout fill all the spaces. Use a rubber kidney to remove the excess grout from the surface of the mosaic before completing the grouting.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the mosaic mirror frame being grouted. A red rubber kidney tool is being used to spread grout into the gaps between the mosaic pieces. Excess grout is being scraped off the surface.

steps.instruction: Use a paper towel to clean the rest of the grout of the tiles and then polish it with a soft cloth.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the mosaic mirror frame after grouting and initial cleaning. The grout lines are visible, and the mosaic pieces are being wiped clean with a paper towel and a soft cloth.

steps.instruction: If you feel your mirror could do with some more inserts or you might want to bring the eye to a particular area, glue the additional inserts in place with flexible tile adhesive. This will also create an interesting 3D effect.
steps.visual_description: A section of the mosaic mirror frame showing additional small inserts being glued onto the surface to add detail and a 3D effect.

steps.instruction: Finish of the edges of the mirror with craft paint - your choice of colour.
steps.visual_description: The edge of the mosaic mirror frame is being painted with craft paint. The paint is applied to the wooden edge to give a finished look.

tips: Try and use different coloured mosaics in the background to those of your inserts so that the inserts stand out better.

If you feel your mirror could do with some more inserts or you might want to bring the eye to a particular area, glue the additional inserts in place with flexible tile adhesive. This will also create an interesting 3D effect.
projects.finished_product_description: A decorative mirror with a mosaic frame, featuring a variety of colorful tiles, inserts, glass pebbles, and beads arranged in a pattern.

projects.name: Valentines Hot Air Balloon Card

steps.instruction: Cut out heart shapes from the patterned paper and plain paper. Cut out small cloud shapes from the white felt or white paper.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a brown card on a green background, with cut-out purple hearts, patterned hearts, and white cloud shapes, alongside scissors, a glue stick, glitter glue, and a pen.

steps.instruction: Fold the A4 brown card in half to create the card base. Glue the plain hearts onto the brown card. Fold the patterned hearts and glue them on top of the plain hearts to create a 3D hot air balloon effect. Glue the white cloud shapes onto the card around the hearts.
steps.visual_description: Image shows the brown card with purple hearts already glued down, and patterned hearts being positioned and glued on top. White cloud shapes are also glued onto the card.

steps.instruction: Use the black fineliner to draw baskets below the hot air balloons and strings connecting them to the hearts. Apply Bostik Glitter Glue to the edges of the purple hearts for decoration.
steps.visual_description: Finished card showing two 3D hot air balloons made of layered hearts, with drawn baskets and strings, and glitter applied to the heart edges. White clouds are also visible.

details.description: Plain hearts as base, patterned hearts folded and layered on top for 3D effect

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Fold the A4 brown card in half. Layer and fold hearts to create a 3D effect for the hot air balloons. Draw baskets and connecting strings with a fineliner. Decorate with glitter glue.

projects.finished_product_description: A handmade Valentines card featuring two 3D hot air balloons made from layered and folded hearts (purple and patterned), with white clouds, drawn baskets, and glitter accents, all on a brown card base.

diagram_descriptions: Large image at the bottom shows the finished Valentines Hot Air Balloon Card, which is a brown card folded in half. It features two 3D hot air balloons made from layered purple and patterned hearts, with glitter on the purple heart edges. White cloud shapes are glued around the balloons. Black fineliner is used to draw baskets below the balloons and connecting strings.

Top-middle image shows the initial setup on a green background: a brown card, a Bostik Glue Stick, a Bostik Glitter Glue pen, scissors, a pen, two cut-out purple hearts, several small patterned heart cut-outs, and two white cloud cut-outs.

Top-right image shows the card in progress on a green background: a brown card with two purple hearts glued down, and patterned hearts being positioned and glued on top to create a 3D effect. Two white cloud shapes are also glued onto the card.
Bottom-right image shows two product blister packs: one for 'Bostik Cut 'n Paste' (25g Glue Stick + Scissors) and another for 'Bostik Rainbow Glitter Glue' (6 x 10.5ml tubes in assorted colors).
